image.altText: Dutton looks serious, part of the frame is filled by the backs of reporters

props.synopsis: ACT politicians Andrew Leigh and David Pocock slam Peter Dutton's commitment today to cut 41,000 Canberra-based public service jobs.

title.children: Pocock, Leigh slam Dutton's commitment to cut Canberra public service

image.altText: A photo of Pope Francis in a frame.

props.synopsis: The former leader of the Catholic Church's Truth, Justice and Healing Council says Pope Francis's leadership centred on inclusion and diversity, not judgement — and that progressive approach created some enemies among Australia's clerical elite.

title.children: Some Catholics anxious about church without Pope Francis holding the reins

image.altText: A woman with short white hair in a navy blue and white stripped button-down shirt stands on a footpath smiling.

props.synopsis: For Deb Stevens Burrangiri aged care respite facility in Canberra's south was a "lifeline" as her mother's dementia progressed, but the ACT's Health Minister says it's unlikely the facility will be the recipient of a promised $10 million federal funding boost should an Albanese government be re-elected.

title.children: Deb wants her 'lifeline' funded but the health minister say it's unlikely

image.altText: A black and white photo of a soldier throwing a pigeon into the air.

props.synopsis: In the dense jungle of New Guinea, April 1944, a patrol of American troops with vital military intel were surrounded by enemy troops when their radios stopped working.

title.children: How US soldiers were saved by a 'rat on wings'

image.altText: Archbishop Charles Balvo

props.synopsis: The late Pope Francis is remembered as "charitable" leader by members of the Catholic Church in Canberra.

title.children: Catholic leaders in Canberra remember Pope Francis as a 'compassionate' leader

image.altText: Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory

props.synopsis: The thief stole a bike, a laptop, a saxophone and a guitar. But it all came tumbling down when the owner of a stolen iPad used the Find My iPad function.

title.children: Thief comes unstuck because of Find My iPad app

image.altText: Three young women performing a double dutch jump rope routine which includes a backflip.

props.synopsis: Most people know rope skipping as a playground activity, but for 12-year-olds Ella Pratley and Heath Malligan it's a highly competitive and technical sport they're preparing to represent Australia in on the world stage.

title.children: Canberra 12yos Heath and Ella are preparing to skip rope for Australia

image.altText: Senate House of Reps generic composite

props.synopsis: ACT residents will be voting for both their House of Representatives member and their two Senate representatives in the federal election on Saturday May 3.

title.children: Voting in the ACT this federal election? Here's what you should know

image.altText: A graphic showing a row of chairs and signage that says 'Medicare' and 'bulk billing availabel'

props.synopsis: Two new surveys have cast doubt on whether the signature health policy of this election campaign can be delivered.

title.children: 'Every month it's a battle': GPs say they won't switch to full bulk-billing

image.altText: a male politician wearing a suit speaking at lectern in front of party members

props.synopsis: The opposition leader is being cautious with his language as he doesn't want to turn off Chinese-Australian voters, as the Coalition did last election, but he also doesn't want to upset those on his right flank.

title.children: Peter Dutton is choosing his words carefully on China

image.altText: Crushed spodumene ore at the Talison Lithium mine in Greenbushes

props.synopsis: The phrase "critical minerals" reflects the demand for them around the world, but China's market dominance means there are traps for new players such as Australia.

title.children: Australia wants to be a critical minerals superpower, but China stands in the way

image.altText: An older man wearing glasses with grey hair delivering a speech at a conference table, looking stern.

props.synopsis: The President of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank has demanded the militant group free the remaining 59 Israeli hostages held in Gaza and hand over its weapons.

title.children: 'You sons of dogs': Palestinian leader blasts Hamas in hostage release demand

image.altText: close up of donald trump as he pouts his lips and raises his eyebrows

props.synopsis: He added that he expects to strike a deal and set the final tariff figure on China over the next two or three weeks.

title.children: Trump says China tariff cuts depend on Beijing's actions

image.altText: A man in religious garb sitting in front of a red curtain, looking on

props.synopsis: As he glided around St Peter's Square in his popemobile on Sunday, the fact he was 88 and had just spent several weeks in hospital somehow seemed a distant memory. Then everything changed.

title.children: Pope Francis's final hours: A simple dinner and a meeting with an adversary

image.altText: A graphic image with a woman (the coroner) and a man (Rolfe) in greyscale, in front of a blue background with hand prints.

props.synopsis: The coroner's findings into the death of Kumanjayi Walker, an Aboriginal man shot by a Northern Territory police officer in 2019, will be handed down on June 10, 2025. It comes after a series of delays that made the coronial inquiry the longest-running and most expensive in the territory's history.

title.children: NT coroner to deliver findings into police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker

image.altText: bruce lehrmann walking outside court

props.synopsis: Rape charges against the former Liberal Party staffer have returned to a Toowoomba court, with a judge growing impatient at arguments between the legal teams.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann rape case back in court as lawyers tangle over brief

image.altText: Eddie Obeid arrives at court to be sentenced for misconduct in public office

props.synopsis: NSW Crime Commissioner Michael Barnes says the decision not to confiscate the money was one he did not want to make.

title.children: Jailed former NSW Labor minister to keep $30m from corrupt coal deal

image.altText: a beachfront carpark is cordoned off

props.synopsis: NSW Police were called to a car park shortly before midnight and found a man, believed to be 18, with a gunshot wound.

title.children: 'Senseless': Teen shot dead in Newcastle car park after group brawl

image.altText: A storm cloud approaching land on an autumn afternoon

props.synopsis: From showers in the east to a chilly dawn service in the west, this is the Anzac Day weather forecast across Australia.

title.children: Parts of Australia's east set to be soaked this Anzac Day

image.altText: A man's hand writing notes in a notebook in front of ASX boards

props.synopsis: The local share market opens higher as global stocks rally following the US president apparently softening his stance on China and the Federal Reserve. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Global markets, ASX rally on softer Trump stance

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australian critical minerals miners gain after PM Albanese pledges investment
The 10 Australians on Bloomberg's list of the world's 500 richest people
Westpac says RBA will cut rates in May by 25 basis points

image.altText: a man in a suit

props.synopsis: Prosecutors say Moon Jae-in has been indicted for alleged bribery over the employment of his former son-in-law at a Thai airline.

title.children: Prosecutors indict former South Korean president Moon Jae-in for bribery

image.altText: A detail of an old photograph showing returned soldiers

props.synopsis: A Queensland historian has researched the stories of Australia's military "rejects" and how they made vital contributions to World War I efforts.

title.children: How the 'rejects' from WWI refused to be cast aside

image.altText: An image of a teenager's hand holding a vape.

props.synopsis: Researchers used the drug Varenicline to block the pleasant effects of nicotine on the brains of a group of 16- to 25-year-olds over a 24-week period.

title.children: Could a pill be the solution to your vaping addiction?

image.altText: A man in a navy suit and tie walks next to a silver sign with the number 3 on it

props.synopsis: The former SA Liberal leader has lost a bid to avoid being convicted over drug supply charges, with a magistrate saying the offending was "too serious" not to record convictions.

title.children: Former SA opposition leader David Speirs convicted over drug supply charges

image.altText: An image of sandstone buildings against a blue sky

props.synopsis: In New Zealand, there is now a conversation about an organisation called Atlas Network and whether or not it has influenced the right-bloc government's agenda.

title.children: Growing questions in NZ about organisation called Atlas Network

image.altText: Trump gives a quizzical gesture at his desk in  the oval office

props.synopsis: How exactly did some of our workplaces become the target of populist politics — and why is it working in the US while in Australia the Coalition has had to rein in its attacks?

title.children: 'Appeals to a base of white men': Dutton tried Trump's workplace tactics

image.altText: Kyneton Football and Netball Club coach speaking to players.

props.synopsis: The AFL is set to review the circumstances around Kyneton Football Netball Club's women's side breaking away from the club, as more women's teams fold across the state.

title.children: AFL to review Kyneton women's team situation as more teams fold

image.altText: An ambulance in Melbourne's CBD.

props.synopsis: Victoria's paramedics union is blaming Ambulance Victoria management for any breaches of COVID restrictions when 40 staff attended a secret 2021 gathering to honour a colleague who had died.

title.children: Ambulance union defends paramedics for attending secret COVID-19 funeral gathering

image.altText: A male lion roaring and showing its sharp teeth.

props.synopsis: A team of archaeologists has found what they claim to be the skeleton of a gladiator who was bitten by a big cat — the first physical evidence of gladiator-animal combat in the Roman Empire.

title.children: Bones suggest a lion gnawed on Roman gladiator's body while he died

image.altText: Norwegian athlete Henriette Jaeger runs around a bend in a 400m race on an indoor track with a rival behind her.

props.synopsis: Norwegian athletes are advised against eating any kind of meat while in China due to the risk of contamination and failed dope tests ahead of two major events due in the country next month.

title.children: Meat off the menu for Norwegian athletes in China over doping fears

image.altText: Cocos polling

props.synopsis: Almost 6,000km from Canberra, voters on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island say they're being treated as an afterthought – at best – by the candidates vying for their vote.

title.children: The polls are open, but Australia's most remote voters are feeling 'forgotten'

image.altText: a donald trump mask and maga hat

props.synopsis: A costume shop that sold out of Trump-style MAGA hats says they are being worn in a "playful, ironic sense". Others say the red cap means much more.

title.children: Anti-woke or a bit of fun? Where MAGA hats are hot items in Australia

image.altText: Harvey Weinstein adjusts his tie as he appears in court in manhattan

props.synopsis: For the first time, prosecutors publicly identified Kaja Sokola and detailed her account of what unfolded between her and the Oscar-winning movie producer in the early 2000s.

title.children: Former model named in Harvey Weinstein's rape retrial

image.altText: Six soldiers in camouflage holding guns stand in the back of a small car looking out

props.synopsis: The attack is the worst on civilians in the country since the 2008 Mumbai terror attack.

title.children: India downgrades ties with Pakistan after fatal attack on Kashmir tourists

image.altText: An old oub with vehicles out the front and Pier Hotel signage on the roof.

props.synopsis: An iconic West Australian pub established in the 1890s will be flattened later this month, and BHP's plans for the site have left Port Hedland locals underwhelmed.

title.children: 'Toughest pub in the world' to be demolished to make way for a park
